story:
Join us to make Pride Uncovered possible! 

Pride Uncovered is a photo book about love and being yourself, whoever and wherever you are. Your support will help us to spread the winning images from the first five editions of Pride Photo Award all over the world!

We ask you to help us publish the photo book Pride Uncovered marking the 5th anniversary of Pride Photo Award. Pride Photo Award is an international contest of photography that shows the diversity of the lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender (LGBT) community.

These photographers (from Russia, Mexico, Vietnam, USA … ) have brought together a collection of powerful, amazing images that show the strength, the courage and the love of people who live in difficult circumstances. They have uncovered surprising and touching stories, from the first Islamic school for transgenders in Indonesia to gay and lesbian soldiers in the USA army. Some photos reveal the intolerance and ignorance many LGBT people are confronted with, while others bring forth a message of hope and love. 


Your Impact

By supporting this book project you will support a powerful message of equality and diversity. The more people view these images, the more successful we will become in advancing acceptance for LGBT people.

  • In exchange for a small contribution, you will receive a unique photography book that tells the stories of people who, like you, want to be accepted, want to love and be loved. Keep it for yourself, give it to a special friend or share it with everyone you know.

  • Moreover, you will be an advocate of the art of more than eighty amazing photographers from all over the world, who often worked under difficult conditions to bring you these powerful stories.


Create a village to raise a book

It takes a village to raise a child, so we are building a community to help produce the book Pride Uncovered: Five Years Pride Photo Award 2010 – 2014.

We ask you to donate € 10 or more to this campaign and to help us reach more people by sharing this campaign with your friends and followers on Twitter, Facebook, Instagram et cetera. That is a MAJOR way to help us! You can use the share tools right here on the site.


A big THANK YOU from Amsterdam for any help you can provide!

PS If the payment (by Paypal and creditcard) on this site forms an obstacle, please don’t hesitate to contact us. We will try to find a solution. You can send an email to Marleen van Toorn or Joeri Kempen: events@pridephotoaward.org




Please scroll down for the following chapters, if the links don't work.*  

Testimonials
Why a photo book?
The featured photographers
What will the book be like?
How will the € 25,000 be spent?
About our perks
What if we raise more money?
What if we don’t reach our goal?
The pride schedule
Contact us

*This service seems to be not compatible with all browsers. We are sorry for that!


First prize, category Documentary 2013: ‘The Pink Choice’ by Hai Thanh Nguyen (Maika Elan), Vietnam

Back to top


Testimonials



Boris Dittrich –  Advocacy Director for the LGBT program of Human Rights Watch

"As Advocacy Director for the LGBT program of Human Rights Watch I often meet people who base their opinion about LGBT people on myths and stereotypes. The only way to counter these myths and stereotypes is by showing people what reality looks like. 
Visibility of the LGBT community is an essential first step to counter these myths and stereotypes. The photo book Pride Uncovered is a welcome addition to that visibility.
Pride Photo Award has brought together photos that tell stories from all over the world. Photos that show the reality of LGBT’s in many different countries. These stories need to be seen and shared, to empower the brave activists in countries where LGBT’s face repression, to further understanding and acceptance in countries where the public opinion is growing more tolerant, and to enlighten open minded people in countries where LGBT’s are generally accepted, about the situation elsewhere. 
Sometimes pictures tell stories that cannot be encompassed in reports. Art is a basic need and is often influential in bringing about much needed change in society.
I wholeheartedly support this book and hope you will support the campaign to make this book reality."


Saskia Laseur – Partner and Civil-Law Notary at Van Doorne, sponsor of the Pride Photo Award contest

“Since its first edition Pride Photo Award has grown to become a unique yearly event in the photography world. Powered almost exclusively by numerous dedicated volunteers, they have managed to attract hundreds of talented photographers all over the world.
I support this campaign, because these amazing photos and this unique event deserve a pride book. I believe in the transformative power of art to show people the beauty and the value of diversity. In diversity there’s beauty and there’s strength. That’s an important message for our company too.”

Anna Wahlgren – Photographer (Pride Photo Award 2013 Leaving one’s tribe)  www.annawahlgrenphotography.com

"We hear more and more about the repression of people from LGBT-communities around the world. With stories on the theme this book has a unique content and is therefore an important project which I hope will be realized. I think it can be an eye-opener to many people and as well be a valuable archive of the lives of LGBT around the world. I am proud to be part of this project."


Cindy Aquino – Photographer (Pride Photo Award 2013 Bond) indienardophotography.blogspot.nl

“I am very honored to be part of this crowdfunding project, as it will serve as an eye opener to people that LGBT’s have something special about them. That they are as Normal as straight people. They are creative and unique in their own way and deserve respect, acceptance and love. This book will help stop stereotype thinking about Lesbians, Gays, Bisexuals and Transgender people.”  

Jasper Groen – Photographer  www.jaspergroen.nl

"Lack of knowledge creates fear. And sometimes fear transforms into hate. As the proverb goes: unknown, unloved. In my eyes, hatred for gay and transgender people is mainly due to a lack of (correct) information. For this reason, the work of Pride Photo Award is so important. The organization is committed to give visibility to gay and transgender people in a balanced way, that is in a way that goes beyond stereotypes.  In recent years, numerous winners have shown that it is not necessary to be afraid or feel hatred towards gay and transgender people. Personally, I am particularly pleased with the positive attention for transgenders within Pride Photo Award. Their emancipation is lagging behind compared to that of gay people, and the statistics on discrimination, dismissal, loneliness and suicide are shocking. The fact that the jury of the Award has chosen a powerful image of trans people as the winning photo in two consecutive editions is very important.
Several pictures from Pride Photo Award appeared in the media worldwide. But media are volatile. What hits the retina today is forgotten tomorrow. Therefore, I think that collecting all pictures in one book can serve as a strong weapon in the fight against ignorance and a good way to increase visibility permanently.  I urge everyone to donate to this charity. ”


Chloe Meynier – Photographer (Pride Photo Award 2013 series Gendernormality) www.chloemeynier.com

"By starting this project, I wanted to raise social consciousness, to build understanding and respect. I want my art to celebrate diversity by making the viewer see in way he/she has not seen before. My goal is to eradicate the fear of the difference in people, as well as the taboo aspect associated with the transgender community. I feel like we are making progress but there is still a long way before we reach equality and respect. This photography project is my way to contribute to make a better world for the future generations and by contributing to the realization of an amazing book, you are also a part of moving the world forward so thank you very much for your support."

Jean-Michel Clajot – Photographer (Pride Photo Award 2011 series LadyBoys, Born to be a Woman)

“The education of my parents was to teach me tolerance and openness.
My work as a photographer allows me to go to communities of people who say they are different. And understand their lives and especially the daily problems they may encounter.
When I photographed the LadyBoy series in Thailand, my goal was to show tolerance in this country. To express through my images that these people have a life like everyone else and above were accepted by families and people in general. I was tired of hearing here in Europe they are just ladyboy people working in prostitution.
When [project manager] Joeri Kempen told me about this project of a photo book about love and being yourself, I found this particularly ambitious and hopeful for a better future in the tolerance of our fellow men. I sincerely hope that this project comes to pass.”


Richard Sandell – Photographer (Pride Photo Award 2013 photo At home with… Andrew and Irene)

"As a researcher who has analysed how viewers respond to images of lgbt people in the public sphere I'm well aware of the power of such images to influence the way people think, feel and act. Efforts, in recent years, to secure more respectful ways of representing gender and sexual diversity have undoubtedly played a critical role in shaping the climate within which discrimination and prejudice against lgbt people can be tackled. But toxic images - negatively stereotypical images that close off opportunities for understanding and respect - are still widespread, fuelling prejudice, discrimination and hate crimes that disproportionately affect young people.
This is why this book and the broader work of the Pride Photo Award is so important. If you can, please pledge your support to be a part of bringing this book and the moving, inspiring and arresting images within it to a broader audience." 


Fabian Weiss – Photographer (Pride Photo Award 2012 series Lala Life)


Jennifer Osborne – Photographer (Pride Photo Award 2012 series Wig Outs)


Manuel Ricardo Garcia – Photographer (Pride Photo Award 2011 series Transmen of the world) www.garcia-photography.com

"I am Manuel Ricardo Garcia, FTM and Transactivist from Munich / Germany. For me it means a lot to support  the photo book 5 years Pride Photo Award, because it helps to make the LGBTIQ community more visible, for me especially the trangender people, in our fight for more tolerance and love in this world."


Chris Belloni – Maker of the documentary film I am Gay and Muslim www.iamgayandmuslim.com

"Ik draag Pride Photo Award en het realiseren van het boek een warm hart toe want ik vind het een prachtig initiatief. Pride Photo Award is in de afgelopen vijf jaar uitgegroeid tot een een evenement met internationale allure dat veel aanzien geniet onder fotografen.
Het maakt LHBT-fotografie in de meest uiteenlopende vormen zichtbaar en zet mensen aan tot denken. Ik ben er trots op dat de fotoserie I am Gay and Muslim erin is opgenomen. Ik steun de crowdfundingcampagne met een bijdrage. Doet u ook mee?"

Willem Poelstra – Photographer www.willempoelstra.nl (Pride Photo Award 2011 series Lowlanders)

"Fotografie is een vluchtig medium geworden. Belangrijke onderwerpen als LGBT worden verdrongen door allerlei niet ter zaken doende onderwerpen omdat iedereen op het internet 'publiceert'. Een boek is een blijvend document, waar je langer bij stil staat en dieper raakt. Het komt op plekken buiten de directe doelgroep en zet die mensen weer tot denken." 

Hinda Schuman – Photographer www.hindaschuman.net (Pride Photo Award 2011 series A True Story)

"The Pride Photo Award is a wonderful initiative that showcases the work of an international group of photographers working with themes relating to the LGBT community. For the public this opens up a world often hidden from view. For photographers, this can be an opportunity to seek out specific stories, or to continue on a relevant project with the hopes of an international audience.
The photographs run the gamut from portrait, to story telling to journalism to fine art- and all genres in between. To have a book produced of winning entries over the first few years of the festival would be a way to reach a broader audience and put the event in an historical light. I would love to be a part of the book, and would be interested in doing whatever I can to support the crowd sourcing fundraising effort."

Bradley Secker – Photographer www.bradleysecker.com (Pride Photo Award 2011 series Iraq’s Gay Refugees)

"As my work in the LGBT field focuses mostly on refugees, and those that have been displaced due to their sexuality and/or gender identity, the publication of this book would make a great difference in bringing their cases to light. There are hundreds of people around the world that are displaced from their homes, or their countries due to their identity. These people have to hide themselves and try to find a safe place to live, a search that may last years or continue their entire lives. As brutal homophobic murders continue in Iraq and neighbouring countries, I hope that the few images I have in this book embed this knowledge in the minds of everyone reading it. Through collective consciousness I hope social attitudes and policy change can take place." 

Lorenzo Triburgo – Photographer triburgo.com (Pride Photo Award 2012 series Transportraits)

"The Pride Photo Award is an interesting and important project, simultaneously advancing contemporary LGBTQ issues and thought-provoking photography. As one of the jurors said to me during the exhibition, first and foremost the photographs must be strong, and I was honored to be among the talented group of winners in 2012. Creating a book of the Pride Photo Award would realize an important archive of worldwide contemporary Queer issues, as well as current photographic ideologies. I believe this book would quickly become a collector's item, and be referenced in classrooms around the world." 

Back to top


Why a photo book?

The photo book will be a powerful tool to help spread these images. A book is lasting, people can keep it and look through it as often as they wish, it can be shared with others or offered as a beautiful gift.

With this collection of photographs you can help us reach out to people, to make them wonder, think and feel. With these images we can create a greater awareness of sexual and gender diversity, help combat stereotypes and increase the acceptance of sexual and gender diversity, allowing people to be themselves and to love without the need to fear. We want to inspire hope and to honour the photographers and the brave people whose stories they tell.


Second prize, category Open 2012: ‘Solitary Fruit’ by Risk Hazekamp, The Netherlands

Back to top

The featured photographers

When we say that the book will contain photos from all over the world, we mean that quite literally. It will comprise works made by photographers from Australia, the Philippines, Mexico, the Netherlands, Russia, Singapore, Slovenia, Uganda, the USA and Vietnam - to mention just a few countries. 


  • Photographers edition 2010: Marjan Bakker; Kael T. Block: Diana Blok; Morad Bouchakour; Jan van Breda; Albert Dijkman; Tara Fallaux; Jasper Groen; Risk Hazekamp; Sabrina van den Heuvel; Paul Koeleman; Erwin Olaf; Ruud van der Peijl; Tania Theodorou; Erwin Venema: Jacquie Maria Wessels; Merel Zwart
  • Photographers edition 2011: Erica Beckman; Michal Lelenthal Brezinski; Jovana Cetkovic; Jean-Michel Clajot; Benedicte Desrus; Trea van Drunen; Gughi Fassino; Manuel Ricardo Garcia; Martijn Gijsbertsen; Paul Koeleman; Anastasia Taylor-Lind; Rogelio Pereda; Ohm Phanpiroj; Willem Poelstra; Hinda Schuman; Bradley Secker; Michael Sharkey; Raoul Vernède; L Weingarten
  • Photographers edition 2012: José Manuel Alorda; Bram Belloni; Guang Hui Chan; Luca Desienna; Diederick Habermehl; Risk Hazekamp; Tobin Bryce Jones; Álvaro Laiz; JJ Levine; Jennifer Lea Osborne; Chris Rijksen; Pacifico Silano; Anna-stina Treumund; Lorenzo Triburgo; Fabian Weiss
  • Photographers edition 2013: Cindy Aquino; Maika Elan; Nicola Ókin Friìoli; Martijn Gijsbertsen; Téo Jaffre; Stefan Jora; Chloë Meynier; Tatjana Plitt; Irina Popova; Richard Sandell; Anna Charlotte Schmid; Joelle de Vries; Anna Wahlgren; Yuan Yuan; Tadej Žnidarčič; Alexia Zuñiga


First prize, category Documentary 2011: 'Persecution of Homosexuality in Uganda' by Benedicte Desrus / SIPA Press, France

Back to top


What will the book be like?

The book Pride Uncovered will feature the winning images from the first five editions of Pride Photo Award, which were selected by juries of internationally acknowledged photography experts such as Stephen Mayes (former director of VII Photo and secretary of World Press Photo in 2004 – 2011), Michiko Kasahari (chief photo curator of the Tokyo Metropolitan Museum of Photography), Jane Jackson (director emeritus of the Sir Elton John Photo Collection), and Christian Caujolle (founder of Agence Vu, Gallery Vu and director of Photo Pnomh Penh).

You can learn more about the previous editions and their juries and themes for each edition on the Pride Photo Award website: 

  • 2010: The Jewel Edition (exhibition without a contest) 
  • 2011: Straight Back At You
  • 2012: Chameleons/Double Life
  • 2013: Extremely Normal
  • 2014: Getting Closer

We will print the book in a 16 x 16 cm (6.3 x 6.3 inches) format, of about 360 pages and 1,000 copies, including 100 limited edition copies. If we raise more than the minimum amount needed to make the book, the first stretch goal will be to increase the format of the book to 21 x 21 cm (8.3 x 8.3 inches). With each stretch goal we will also increase the number of copies, so we can spread the book even further.

The book will be printed in the Netherlands to a very high standard. Our printer Lecturis works closely with graphic designers, artists, photographers, communication agencies, art galleries, museums, governmental agencies and corporate organizations. Lecturis specializes in art and photography books. They print with a sublime raster which guarantees that the print quality of the (photo) plates will be outstanding

Summary of the specifications:

  • Size: small intimate square format of 16 x 16 cm (6.3 x 6.3 inches)
  • Pages: 360 pages
  • Binding: thread sewn
  • Language: bilingual, English and Dutch
  • Graphic design: Kees van Veenendaal


Third prize, category Documentary 2012: 'Trans Islam' by Luca Desienna, Italy

Back to top


How will the € 25,000 be spent?

Our primary goal is € 25,000 Euros (approximately $ 33,967). The sum will cover the costs of creating and producing 1,000 Pride Uncovered Books:

  • € 8,000 for paper, printing and binding
  • € 2,500 for graphic design
  • € 2,500 for text, editing, proof reading, translating, etc.
  • € 2,000 for the curator who makes the photo selection 
  • € 6,000 for shipping costs, perks (like limited edition, miniature photo panels)
  • € 2,000 for sending several copies of the book to our photographers (around 80) all over the world
  • € 2,000 fee (Indiegogo and PayPal)


Second Prize, category Documentary 2013: ‘Leaving one’s tribe’ by Anna Wahlgren, Sweden

Back to top


About our perks

We have wonderful perks for you to choose from, please find them listed in the right-hand column. The following perks require a bit of explanation:

  • € 100 Perk — As a Miniature Collector you will receive, among other perks, this miniature photo panel with a winning photo of your choice. (Not all photos are available.) To select a photo, please see the Pride Photo Award website: www.pridephotoaward.org

         The miniature photo panel 

  • € 250 Perk — As an Art Supporter you will receive an unsigned artist proof. A 20 x 20 cm (7.87 x 7.87 inches) print of one of the winning photos. (Not all photos are available.) To select a photo, please see the Pride Photo Award website: www.pridephotoaward.org
  • € 2,500 Perk — For the Art Collector perk you can choose a signed print of one the winning photos, as normally sold by the photographer. Before funding please contact us and let us know which photo from which artist you would prefer. Due to the limitations of existing limited editions, not all photos by all artists will be available. Hence we will check the availability of your chosen photo for you before you select this option. See the links here beneath to make your choice:
          Pride Photo Award 2010
          Pride Photo Award 2011
          Pride Photo Award 2012
          Pride Photo Award 2013

  • The other perk option at € 2,500 is a private concert by Dolly Bellefleur for you and your friends at your home. (This perk is limited to one funder and is available in the Netherlands only.) For more information about this Dutch Artist: www.dollybellefleur.nl and a video on youtube.


Third prize, category Extremely Normal 2013: 'Gay Warriors a series of portraits of same-sex couples in the US Military' by Tatjana Plitt, Australia

Back to top


What if we raise more money?

The primary target of € 25,000 is the minimum needed to create and produce the book. If we succeed in raising more money, we plan to increase the format of the book and print extra copies.

These are our other stretch goals:

  • Larger size: 21 x 21 cm (8.27 x 8.27 inches) instead of 16 x 16 cm (6.3 x 6.3 inches).
  • Includes postcards of a selected number of winning photos which you can use to spread the photos even further.
  • A box will be made to house the book and the postcards, increasing its appeal as a gift.


They drink beer, they are part of local governement and they are symbol of good luck for their family: they are Muxes, more than 3.000 homosexuals of the 'pueblo oaxacaqueno de Juchitan'. (Oaxaca-Mexico). They are considered a sign of luck, a blessing. ”Thanks to God, we have one of them in every family... they are like women, they work as a man, but they wash, cook, clean the house and when the other sons will get married and leave, they will stay and look after their old parents”. First Prize: ‘Princesses in a land of machos’ by Nicola Ókin Frioli, Mexico

Back to top


What if we don't reach our goal?

We guarantee to refund your money if for whatever reason the book project cannot go through as planned, for instance if we don't raise the minimumamount needed.


Second prize, category Chameleons/Double Life 2012: 'Gender as a Performance' by Chris Rijksen, the Netherlands, Winner of the Pride Photo Award 2012

Back to top


The pride schedule

The Pride Photo Award contest starts each year in April and the winners are announced in early July. Since the book will also include the 2014 winners, the book schedule is tied to the contest schedule.

  • Crowdfunding campaign: February – March 2014
  • Designing and editing the first part of the book: March – June 2014
  • Selection of the 2014 winners: First week of July 2014
  • Editing the 2014 part of the book: July – Early August 2014
  • Printing the book: August 2014
  • Launch of the book: End of August 2014 during the exhibition
  • Exhibition 2014 in Amsterdam: 29 August – 26 October 2014


Second prize, category Gender 2012: 'Transmongolian' by Alvaro Laiz, Spain

Back to top


Contact us

Pride Photo Award

Joeri Kempen (Project Manager Pride Photo Award) / 
Marleen van Toorn (Crowdfunding Campagne Manager)
Rozenstraat 8
1016 NX Amsterdam
events@pridephotoaward.org
+31(0)6-52.010.227
www.pridephotoaward.org


Back to top
story_txt:
Join us to make Pride Uncovered possible! Pride Uncovered is a photo book about love and being yourself, whoever and wherever you are. Your support will help us to spread the winning images from the first five editions of Pride Photo Award all over the world!We
ask you to help us publish the photo book Pride Uncovered marking the 5th
anniversary of Pride Photo Award. Pride Photo Award is an international contest of photography that shows the diversity of the lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender (LGBT) community.
These photographers (from Russia, Mexico, Vietnam, USA … ) have
brought together a collection of powerful, amazing images that
show the strength, the courage and the love of people who live in
difficult circumstances. They
have uncovered surprising and touching stories, from the first
Islamic school for transgenders in Indonesia to gay and lesbian
soldiers in the USA army. Some photos reveal the intolerance and
ignorance many LGBT people are confronted with, while others bring forth a
message of hope and love. Your ImpactBy
supporting this book project you
will support a powerful message of equality
and diversity. The more people view
these images, the more successful we will become in advancing acceptance for LGBT people.


In exchange for a small contribution, you will receive a unique photography book that tells the stories of people who, like you, want to be accepted,
want to	love and be loved. Keep it for yourself, give it to a
	special friend or share it with everyone you know.


Moreover,
	you will be an advocate
	of
	the art of more than eighty amazing photographers from all over the
	world, who often
	worked under difficult conditions to bring you these powerful stories.


Create a village to raise a bookIt
takes a village to raise a child, so we are building a community to
help produce the book Pride
Uncovered: Five Years Pride Photo Award 2010 – 2014.

We ask you to donate € 10 or more to this campaign and to help us reach more people by sharing this campaign with your friends and followers on Twitter, Facebook, Instagram et cetera. That is a MAJOR way to help us!
You can use the share tools right here on the site.A
big THANK YOU from Amsterdam for any help you can provide!
PS If the
payment (by Paypal and creditcard) on this site forms an obstacle, please don’t
hesitate to contact us. We will try to find a solution. You can send an email
to Marleen van Toorn or Joeri Kempen: events@pridephotoaward.org 
Please scroll down for the following chapters, if the links don't work.*

We are sorry for that!First prize, category Documentary 2013: ‘The Pink Choice’ by Hai Thanh Nguyen (Maika Elan), VietnamBack to top
TestimonialsBoris Dittrich –  Advocacy Director for the LGBT program of Human Rights Watch
"As Advocacy Director for the LGBT program
of Human Rights Watch I often meet people who base their opinion about LGBT people on myths
and stereotypes. The only way to counter these myths and stereotypes is by
showing people what reality looks like. Visibility of the LGBT
community is an essential first step to counter these myths and stereotypes.
The photo book Pride Uncovered is a
welcome addition to that visibility.Pride Photo Award has
brought together photos that tell stories from all over the world. Photos that
show the reality of LGBT’s in many different countries. These stories need to
be seen and shared, to empower the brave activists in countries where LGBT’s
face repression, to further understanding and acceptance in countries where the
public opinion is growing more tolerant, and to enlighten open minded people in
countries where LGBT’s are generally accepted, about the situation
elsewhere. 
Sometimes pictures tell stories that cannot be encompassed in reports. Art is a basic need and is often influential in bringing about much needed change in society.I wholeheartedly support this book and hope you
will support the campaign to make this book reality."Saskia Laseur – Partner and Civil-Law Notary at Van Doorne, sponsor of the Pride Photo Award contest

“Since its first edition Pride Photo Award has grown to become a unique yearly event in the photography world. Powered almost exclusively by numerous dedicated volunteers, they have managed to attract hundreds of talented photographers all over the world.I support this campaign, because these amazing photos and this unique event deserve a pride book. I believe in the transformative power of art to show people the beauty and the value of diversity. In diversity there’s beauty and there’s strength. That’s an important message for our company too.”
Anna Wahlgren – Photographer (Pride Photo Award 2013 Leaving one’s tribe)  www.annawahlgrenphotography.com"We hear more and more about the repression of people from LGBT-communities around the world. With stories on the theme this book has a unique content and is therefore an important project which I hope will be realized. I think it can be an eye-opener to many people and as well be a valuable archive of the lives of LGBT around the world. I am proud to be part of this project."Cindy Aquino – Photographer (Pride Photo Award 2013 Bond) indienardophotography.blogspot.nl
“I
am very honored to be part of this crowdfunding project, as it will serve as an
eye opener to people that LGBT’s have something special about them. That they
are as Normal as straight people. They are creative and unique in their own way
and deserve respect, acceptance and love. This book will help stop stereotype
thinking about Lesbians, Gays, Bisexuals and Transgender people.”  
Jasper Groen – Photographer  www.jaspergroen.nl

"Lack
of knowledge creates fear. And sometimes fear transforms into hate. As the
proverb goes: unknown, unloved. In my eyes, hatred for gay and
transgender people is mainly due to a lack of (correct) information. For this
reason, the work of Pride Photo Award is so important. The organization is
committed to give visibility to gay and transgender people in a balanced way,
that is in a way that goes beyond stereotypes.  In recent years, numerous
winners have shown that it is not necessary to be afraid or feel hatred towards gay and transgender people.
Personally, I am particularly pleased with the positive attention for
transgenders within Pride Photo Award. Their emancipation is lagging behind
compared to that of gay people, and the statistics on discrimination,
dismissal, loneliness and suicide are shocking. The fact that the jury of
the Award has chosen a powerful image of trans people as the winning
photo in two consecutive editions is very
important.
Several
pictures from Pride Photo Award appeared in the media worldwide. But media are
volatile. What hits the retina today is forgotten tomorrow. Therefore, I think
that collecting all pictures in one book can serve as a strong weapon in the
fight against ignorance and a good way to increase visibility permanently.  I
urge everyone to donate to this charity. ”Chloe Meynier – Photographer (Pride Photo Award 2013 series Gendernormality) www.chloemeynier.com"By starting this project, I wanted to raise social consciousness, to build understanding and respect. I want my art to celebrate diversity by making the viewer see in way he/she has not seen before. My goal is to eradicate the fear of the difference in people, as well as the taboo aspect associated with the transgender community. I feel like we are making progress but there is still a long way before we reach equality and respect. This photography project is my way to contribute to make a better world for the future generations and by contributing to the realization of an amazing book, you are also a part of moving the world forward so thank you very much for your support."Jean-Michel Clajot – Photographer (Pride Photo Award 2011 series LadyBoys, Born to be a Woman)
“The education of
my parents was to teach me tolerance and openness.My work as a
photographer allows me to go to communities of people who say they are
different. And understand their lives and especially the daily problems they
may encounter.When I photographed
the LadyBoy series in Thailand, my goal was to show tolerance in this country.
To express through my images that these people have a life like everyone else
and above were accepted by families and people in general. I
was tired of hearing here in Europe they are just ladyboy people working in
prostitution.When [project
manager] Joeri Kempen told me about this project of a photo book about love and
being yourself, I found this particularly ambitious and hopeful for a better
future in the tolerance of our fellow men. I sincerely hope that this project
comes to pass.”

Richard Sandell – Photographer (Pride Photo Award 2013 photo At home with… Andrew and Irene)"As a researcher who has analysed how viewers respond to images of lgbt people in the public sphere I'm well aware of the power of such images to influence the way people think, feel and act. Efforts, in recent years, to secure more respectful ways of representing gender and sexual diversity have undoubtedly played a critical role in shaping the climate within which discrimination and prejudice against lgbt people can be tackled. But toxic images - negatively stereotypical images that close off opportunities for understanding and respect - are still widespread, fuelling prejudice, discrimination and hate crimes that disproportionately affect young people.This is why this book and the broader work of the Pride Photo Award is so important. If you can, please pledge your support to be a part of bringing this book and the moving, inspiring and arresting images within it to a broader audience." 
Fabian Weiss – Photographer (Pride Photo Award 2012 series Lala Life)Jennifer Osborne – Photographer (Pride Photo Award 2012 series Wig Outs)Manuel
Ricardo Garcia – Photographer (Pride Photo Award 2011 series Transmen of the world) www.garcia-photography.com
"I am Manuel
Ricardo Garcia, FTM and Transactivist from Munich / Germany. For me it means a
lot to support  the photo book 5 years
Pride Photo Award, because it helps to make the LGBTIQ community more visible,
for me especially the trangender people, in our fight for more tolerance and
love in this world."Chris Belloni – Maker of the documentary film I am Gay and Muslim www.iamgayandmuslim.com
"Ik draag Pride Photo Award en het realiseren van het boek een warm
hart toe want ik vind het een prachtig initiatief. Pride Photo Award is in de
afgelopen vijf jaar uitgegroeid tot een een evenement met internationale allure
dat veel aanzien geniet onder fotografen.
Het maakt LHBT-fotografie in de meest uiteenlopende vormen zichtbaar en zet
mensen aan tot denken. Ik ben er trots op dat de fotoserie I am Gay and
Muslim erin is opgenomen. Ik steun de crowdfundingcampagne met een
bijdrage. Doet u ook mee?"Willem Poelstra – Photographer www.willempoelstra.nl (Pride Photo Award 2011 series Lowlanders)"Fotografie is een vluchtig medium geworden. Hinda

I would love to be a part of the book, and would be interested in doing
whatever I can to support the crowd sourcing fundraising effort."
Bradley Secker – Photographer www.bradleysecker.com (Pride Photo Award 2011 series Iraq’s Gay Refugees)"As my work in the LGBT field focuses mostly on refugees, and those that have been displaced due to their sexuality and/or gender identity, the publication of this book would make a great difference in bringing their cases to light. € 2,500 for text, editing, proof reading, translating, etc.
€ 2,000 for the curator who makes the photo selection 
€ 6,000 for shipping costs, perks (like limited edition, miniature
photo panels)
€ 2,000 for sending several copies of the book to our photographers (around 80) all over
the world
€ 2,000 fee (Indiegogo and PayPal)


Second Prize, category Documentary 2013: ‘Leaving one’s tribe’ by Anna Wahlgren, Sweden

Back to top
About our perksWe
have wonderful perks for you to choose from, please find them listed in the right-hand column. The following perks require a bit of explanation:



€ 100
Perk — As a Miniature Collector you will receive, among other perks,
this miniature photo panel with a winning photo of your choice. (Not all photos are available.) To select a photo, please see the Pride Photo Award website: www.pridephotoaward.org
         The miniature photo panel 
€ 250
Perk		 — As an Art Supporter you will receive an unsigned artist proof. A
20 x 20 cm (7.87 x 7.87 inches) print of one of the winning photos. (Not all photos are available.) To select a photo, please see the Pride Photo Award website: www.pridephotoaward.org

€ 2,500
Perk	 — For the Art Collector perk you can choose a signed
print of one the winning photos, as normally sold by the photographer. Before funding please contact us and
let us know which photo from which artist you would prefer. Due to the limitations of
existing limited editions, not all photos by all artists will be
available. Hence we will check the availability of your chosen photo for you before you select this option. See the links here beneath to make your choice:
          Pride Photo Award 2010          Pride Photo Award 2011          Pride Photo Award 2012          Pride Photo Award 2013The other perk option at € 2,500 is a
 private concert by Dolly Bellefleur for you and your friends at your 
home. (This perk is limited to one funder and is available in the 
Netherlands only.) For more information about this Dutch Artist: www.dollybellefleur.nl and a video on youtube. Third prize, category Extremely Normal 2013: 'Gay Warriors a series of portraits of same-sex couples in the US Military' by Tatjana Plitt, Australia
Back to top

What if we raise more money?The
primary target of € 25,000 is the minimum needed to create and produce
the book. If we succeed in raising more money, we plan to increase the format of the book and print extra copies. 


These
are our other stretch goals:


Larger
size: 21 x 21 cm (8.27 x 8.27 inches) instead of 16 x 16 cm (6.3 x
6.3 inches).

Includes
postcards of a selected number of winning photos which you can use to
spread the photos even further.

A
box will be made to house the book and the postcards, increasing its
appeal as a gift.

They drink beer, they are part of local governement and they are symbol of good luck for their family: they are Muxes, more than 3.000 homosexuals of the 'pueblo oaxacaqueno de Juchitan'. (Oaxaca-Mexico). They are considered a sign of luck, a blessing. ”Thanks to God, we have one of them in every family... they are like women, they work as a man, but they wash, cook, clean the house and when the other sons will get married and leave, they will stay and look after their old parents”. First Prize: ‘Princesses in a land of machos’ by Nicola Ókin Frioli, Mexico
Back to top

What if we don't reach our goal?
We guarantee to refund your money if for whatever reason the book project cannot go through as planned, for instance if we don't raise the minimumamount needed.Second prize, category Chameleons/Double Life 2012: 'Gender as a Performance' by Chris Rijksen, the Netherlands, Winner of the Pride Photo Award 2012Back to top

Pride Photo Award contest starts each year in April and the winners
are announced in early July. Since the book will also include the 2014
winners, the book schedule is tied to the contest schedule.

story:
Hello! We’re Makewild, a group of longtime friends from Maine now based in Venice, CA. In 2016, we traveled to Cuba to make a film about a group of athletes who risked their freedom to legitimize surfing on the island. If you can imagine, until recently, surfing in Cuba was illegal. 

Those in pursuit of the elusive barrel were made outlaws, risking their boards being confiscated or getting arrested. These surfers took the sport into their own hands, passionately shaping surfboards out of refrigerator doors, ceiling tiles and whatever else they could find. They paddled out to score a few moments of freedom. They inspired us. They instilled in us a new appreciation for the sport we love. They taught us a new meaning of adventure. Now we want to share these stories with the world.   
 

ABOUT THE BOOK 

The Cuba Unknown is a photo book on a mission to inspire both travelers and surfers. Through photos and stories from our time on the island with local friends, we aim to reveal a lesser-known side of Cuba, beyond the old cars and decaying buildings. The book offers tips for those intrigued to make the journey, without being a total gringo.

 

WHAT YOU'RE FUNDING

Purchasing the book and supporting the project at any level helps us finish our feature film, Havana Libre, which follows the effort to legitimize surfing in Cuba. 

WHAT'S INSIDE

180 FSC-certified pages kinda like these below (Heidleberg offset printing on art-grade paper), sandwiched between an embossed hardcover like you saw above.

 

 

OUR FRIENDS AND SUBJECTS

In the book, you'll see a lot of this guy. This is Frank Gonzalez. We became friends early on. Apart from being a pretty stellar surfer, Frank is a true craftsman. Seeing him make a surfboard out of a refrigerator door is a true testament to the resourcefulness of the Cuban people in the face of scarcity. 

You'll also meet Yaya Guerrero, one of the few women surfing on the island. She's a total bad ass and at the forefront of the surf movement  to legitimize the sport in time for the 2020 Olympics. 

 

TRAVEL

Where to Explore:

You'll get insight to our favorite spots: whats worth seeing in Havana, the surrounding areas outside the tourist zones, and most importantly - amazing and hard to find gems around the island.

From recently discovered surf spots to waterfalls and urban destinations, this book contains a timely glimpse of the lesser known side of Cuba, plus a few good stories about what to avoid doing when you take the leap and visit this life changing island. 

 

 

ARTWORK

Illustrations and Maps

We partnered with the incredible artist, Allison Kunath, to create 15 original line drawings to compliment our photography, inspired by our travels in Cuba. Her artwork in the image above shares the order of hand signals (left to right) that you'll need to hail a local route-taxi in Havana.

You will also find one of a kind maps to help your explorations on the island (by our very own Corey Mclean).

 

OTHER REWARDS

^Postcards ^

A pack of 10 unique photos from the book, presented in postcard format to send to your favorite explorers.

^Prints^

Select your favorite photo from our recent show and have it printed on beautiful archival paper 12" x 18". These are limited, first-run signed and numbered prints. *delivered unframed*

^Photo Workshop^

Join us in LA for a two-day photo workshop. We'll treat you to a dinner on the beach (just like this one) and teach you some tricks of the trade from behind the lens. *Travel and lodging not included

 

SHARE YOUR LOVE OF THE UNKNOWN!

We really appreciate the generosity in helping us bring this story, and  to life. We'd be even more thankful if you could share this campaign on social media. Just be sure to include a clickable link to TheCubaUnknown.com and tag us @Makewild. Here's a sample post to get you going:

“Stoked to support a project my friends at @Makewild have put together - if you’re looking for a unique gift or something for the surfer/explorer in your life, you'll want to check this out! TheCubaUnknown.com”

story:
"My wife is a R.N. so I have been able to make a go at this without having to take a second job. I couldn't work a second job anyways because our parents are older and are living with us now. I need to be flexible during the week. Ya know...for them."



Hi my name is Justin Connors and I am the creator of People of NB Farmers Markets. I am really excited to share my project with you and I truly hope that you will connect with it and feel the need to get these people's stories out there.

I used to own Fired Pizza Co. at a farmers market and now I am venturing into photography as a career. 


People of NB Farmers Markets first came in my mind when I was a vendor at a local market. I remember walking around during the down time and having heartfelt conversations with different vendors about the fun, hardships, and rewards of being a vendor at one of New Brunswick's Farmers Markets. 

The market is one of New Brunswick's oldest traditions and thousands of people head to them every single weekend. Sometimes we can walk past these people very quickly, or purchase their product without stopping to think about the human element or about what went into the creation of their products.

These vendors are people, they have stories to be told, they have life lessons to be taught. 

Through doing this I want to create a sense of community and get people to increase their pride in where they come from. Local markets are the lifeblood of our communities. I really believe that. We need to get out and really get behind our farmers and artisans.

Perhaps someone in St. Andrews  will see this and never knew there was a guy who makes local pepperoni at the market in Fredericton! This might nudge them to take that drive and see our beautiful province!

"What is the hardest part about setting up in the cold?"
"Well the hardest part is not setting up in the cold but it is keeping me and my girlfriend out of the cold if you know what I mean."


I love photography. I study photography every day and am thinking about it right before I go to bed and when I wake up. I live to create memorable images.

I really feel that images can connect with the storytelling part of our brain. Images can make 100 people feel 100 different emotions. Interviewing the vendors allows me to get into their thinking and lets me extract interesting quotes to accompany the images. The quotes can really leave a lasting impact and allow you to connect deeply with the photograph. It will allow you to experience the vendors on a completely different level and will give a glimpse into their lives and allow you to see the passion they weave into their craft.

I truly believe in living locally and this project will help make us aware of how special our province is and how many different and incredibly skilled people there are that live in it. It will get people thinking about what it means to support local and put a face to the farmers and artisans that make up our culture here in New Brunswick. 

Proof I can take pictures

Her: "Hey Mr. Photographer come over here! Come here! Take a picture of me serving this fine gentleman right here."
Me: "haha sure thing!"
I lift my camera and start snapping photos.
Her: "What publication is this for anyways? who are you taking photos for?"
Me: "Just for a personal photography project"
She starts chuckling and waves me off.
Her "Oh never mind then.." *as she walks away chuckling*


I want to travel around the province this summer and document as many markets as I possibly can. I want to hit the big markets, the small markets, the markets people didn't even know existed. 

I am going to run a blog to document my travels as well as release 3-5 images per week on the blog and fb page. While in the different communities I am also going to take some time to tell a story about the community and get some photos from around New Brunswick.

 To do this it takes a little bit of cash. I don't have it out of pocket and that is why I am asking you. I need some equipment, gas money, a little bit to offset my needing to take on clients, and I want to be able to spend some money with the vendors while I am visiting. I really do not feel the amount I am asking for is an insane or unrealistic amount and I am fully confident there are people who will feel strongly about a project of this nature.

 If I reach the goal and people want to continue donating I will add on objectives as we increase the dollar amount. For example if we reach a certain point I will produce an art show based off my travels, or a photo book with the collection of images in it. 

"Is this what you do now? full time?"
"I am actually on leave from doing social work so starting this has worked out nicely"
"Has social work prepared you for this in any way?"
"Well I guess it teaches you how to deal with different people from different backgrounds, my other job however taught me way more then social work"
"Other job?"
"I was a bartender for 10 years"


I am going to be posting my photos and profiles as I travel on our facebook page and upcoming blog. If you donate, you will get first look at all of these. You will also be the first to find out any news I have about my travels and the project itself.

If it ever comes to the point where I do an art show you will also get invited to an exclusive launch party for the show where I will hope to have tons of local products and vendors present for you to meet.

I also have some pretty cool perks in the sidebar that I hope you will take advantage of.

For the prints perk you choose your print from here https://www.flickr.com/photos/justinconnors/sets/72157643708738825/

"What would you want the public to know about life as a vendor?"
"If people could truly see how much we love interacting with them. Also they really need to know that for most of us this is not a big lucrative business. We are pouring our heart and are souls into our products because we care so passionately about what we are doing."
"It must feel great when people return and compliment your product" 
"They don't even realize. For them to come in and say hey I really loved that coffee! It makes everything worth it."

That is perfectly fine! I understand!  If you could share our facebook page and this page with your friends I would be forever grateful! 

Keep in touch:

The Facebook Project

Twitter: @140justin

Where I post my photos

story:
My name is Alex. I've been practicing and studying photography for many years and I now feel that I am nearly ready to become a professional photographer. My dream is to be able to travel the world and document that beautiful thing called 'life'.

In just under a year I am hoping to be able to set off on my journey, but I have a problem; I don't have the photography equipment I need and what I need is quite expensive, especially with my low income.

What I will use the funds for

Becoming a photographer can be very expensive and i can´t do it without your support.

With the funds i raise here i will upgrade to a better camera, get several lenses, filters, lights, editing software, cover the cost of hosting, business cards and some marketing.

I will be eternally grateful for your support!

Love, cheers and many thanks to everyone!

I'm a photographer and now I'm in Brussels!

Now I have only my CANON and my MAC with me, but I would to set up a professional photography studio for job.


Shooting Valentina

  • Take a room that will allow the required space for the studio
  • Get some backdrops
  • Buy the proper lighting and tripod

YOU GET:

  • A great thank you
  • One shooting session
  • Your digital photo book

See the galley for a preview of my style

story:
"Waterford, A County Revealed"

Hi, I'm George  Munday,  a professional landscape photographer, living in Ireland. My project is  a large, full color, coffee-table book called "Waterford, A County Revealed", a collection of beautiful photographs that takes the reader on an illustrated journey through the landscape and heritage of County Waterford.

But I really need your help to publish it.

The book is finished, designed and ready to go, but I need to raise €13,500 to cover the cost of printing 1,000 copies to the superb quality that the photography and book deserves. So I'm turning to people living in County Waterford, the wider Waterford dispora, photographers and book collectors to ask for contributions. In exchange I'm offering a number of perks, that includes among other things, pre-released signed copies of the book; an exclusive selection of signed, limited edition, art prints; and even guided photo-tours of the county.

Your contribution can help this unique book to see the light of day, and in turn, bring Waterford's exquisite landscape and ancient heritage  to a wider audience.

Why County Waterford?
When I relocated here, I began shooting my new county which, if I'm honest, greatly exceeded my expectations; and I literally threw myself into exploring every nook, and every cranny, of this delightful little county, along with its heritage and history. It was only later that I discovered that there were no "coffee table" style books available  about one of Ireland's most beautiful counties.

This unique book is for people who live in Waterford. For people, who as part of the Waterford diaspora, live a long way from the county, and who would like to remind themselves - and their  families - of the beauty of their homeland. It's for visitors who chance upon this lovely region and would like to have a permament momento to remember it by.

But it's also fellow photographers, for book collectors and for people who just enjoy stunning landscapes.

I've put a lot of thought into the book's layout because I wanted it to flow easily and logically for the reader, so it's been laid out in the form of a circular journey, accompanied by a hand-drawn map. Starting in the city of Waterford - the oldest city in Ireland, the journey heads west along the coast taking in fishing ports; the old mining industry of the Copper Coast; continuing on to the county town of Dungarvan and Gaelic speaking 'An Ring'. From there it continues up the Blackwater River, over the Knockmealdown and Comeragh Mountains, taking in villages, towns, historic castles and charming gardens, to finish near the city.

Photographing the county's many locations, was an idyllic vocation that lasted six years, during which time I frequently made repeat trips to ensure that each location was captured in the right light, and at exactly the right moment. The huge number of photographs has been edited to just over 125, most at full page or double-spread size, and each accompanied by an extensive caption.

The Foreword
With the photography completed, this was one finishing touch needed before it could be published. I wanted someone who is a travel writer, someone who lives in Waterford, and above all, someone who appreciates its beauty. I had ample time whilst roaming the coast and mountains to think about it. My conclusion was that Dervla Murphy, the Irish author of over 24 adventure travel books covering the world from Ireland to India, Cuba to Capetown. Now an octogenerian, Dervla still travels, still writes and still lives in Lismore and was the perfect choice. I was delighted when, on showing her my landscape work, she liked it, and enthusiastically agreed to write a passage in her own inimatable style.

Who am I?
Since leaving photography college 40 years ago, I have worked in a number of genres. First as a photojournalist, then an advertising photographer, until I eventually specialised as a landscape photograper during my time as co-director of Slidefile, the photo-agency. During those years my work appeared in countless books, from large panoramic books to small Irish guide books for Reader's Digest and other international publishers; along with innumerable magazines and calendars.

When I re-located to County Waterford ten years ago, I set up Copper Coast Workshops, to  teach digital photography, and conduct guided photo-tours.  Notwithstanding the fact that I'm now officially 'retired', my enjoyment when shooting the landscape has increased, and I still work on a very occasional, freelance basis for Tourism Ireland...

"George’s love for his adopted country and especially of his adopted county of Waterford is reflected in the quality of the imagery he has consistently produced on commission for Tourism Ireland.  Imagery that has captured the imagination of and encouraged visitors to this island of Ireland" ....Patrick Lennon, Acting Content Manager, Tourism Ireland,

"Since George retired and, to quote him, 'returned to landscape photography for passion, rather than profit', it's been an enjoyable few years following his work on his blog. He studies his subject in depth and the photography shot for his new book illustrates and reveals the rich, varied landscape and heritage of County Waterford to perfection" .... Shane O'Neill, Aspect Photography, Waterford.

Why your support is so important
The book is now designed and ready to print, each part has been thoroughly and expertly compiled; the images, layout and design, dust jacket, interior pages and binding; and it's my fervant hope that I will be able to see it in print form.

However, with 132 pages of superlative quality at a size of 10.5" X 11.75",  in a hard cover, it is very expensive. Which is why I need your support; and this is where Indiegogo and more especially - you - come in, because by backing this project, you can help me to achieve my goal.

It's not without reward. To the right, is the list of the Perks that I'm offering for your support. Designed to give excellent value, the amounts are substantially less than the combined retail value of the items. For example, the book is substantially below the anticipated shop price; the Limited Edition Gallery prints - just 20 of each are considerably below my normal gallery prices. The 10 photographs, represent a small sample of the photography in the book and can be seen by clicking the Gallery tab above.

Your financial support will ensure that the book will be immaculately finished, and you can show off this beautiful book and say, “I helped make it happen”.

If we are fortunate enough to reach our goal, then the book will be available in August this year (2013).  If we are doubly fortunate to have an excess, it will initially be put towards enhancing existing perks and adding one or two new ones. 

The  Waterford bookshops have seen the book in digital form and would like to stock it, so we may also print a small number of additional copies. However, it's very unlikely that it will be available through on-line or overseas book shops.

So please, please keep on contributing until the end of the campaign.  

Whether you are able, or unable to take advantage of the perks, it would be a great help if you would share this project with your friends and colleagues through your social networks, Facebook, Twitter, Google+, blogs and emails etc. The more folk that know about it, the better its chance of succeeding.

However, this Indiegogo project is an all-or-nothing situation. If the book is to be published, the project must meet its funding goal within the time limit of 35 days. If it doesn't, no money changes hands - but it's unlikely that the book will ever be published.


Thank you for your support, any amount, any help, will be greatly appreciated.

George Munday
story_txt:
"Waterford, A County Revealed"
Hi, I'm George  Munday,  a professional landscape photographer, living in Ireland. My project is  a large, full color, coffee-table book called "Waterford, A County Revealed", a collection of beautiful photographs that takes the reader on an illustrated journey through the landscape and heritage of County Waterford.
But I really need your help to publish it.The book is finished, designed and ready to go, but I need to raise €13,500 to cover the cost of printing 1,000 copies to the superb quality that the photography and book deserves. So I'm turning to people living in County Waterford, the wider Waterford dispora, photographers and book collectors to ask for contributions. In exchange I'm offering a number of perks, that includes among other things, pre-released signed copies of the book; an exclusive selection of signed, limited edition, art prints; and even guided photo-tours of the county.
Your contribution can help this unique book to see the light of day, and in turn, bring Waterford's exquisite landscape and ancient heritage  to a wider audience. 
Why County Waterford?When I relocated here, I began shooting my new county which, if I'm honest, greatly exceeded my expectations; and I literally threw myself into exploring every nook, and every cranny, of this delightful little county, along with its heritage and history. It was only later that I discovered that there were no "coffee table" style books available  about one of Ireland's most beautiful counties. This unique book is for people who live in Waterford. For people, who as part of the Waterford diaspora, live a long way from the county, and who would like to remind themselves - and their  families - of the beauty of their homeland. It's for visitors who chance upon this lovely region and would like to have a permament momento to remember it by.
But it's also fellow photographers, for book collectors and for people who just enjoy stunning landscapes.I've put a lot of thought into the book's layout because I wanted it to flow easily and logically for the reader, so it's been laid out in the form of a circular journey, accompanied by a hand-drawn map. Starting in the city of Waterford - the oldest city in Ireland, the journey heads west along the coast taking in fishing ports; the old mining industry of the Copper Coast; continuing on to the county town of Dungarvan and Gaelic speaking 'An Ring'. From there it continues up the Blackwater River, over the Knockmealdown and Comeragh Mountains, taking in villages, towns, historic castles and charming gardens, to finish near the city. Photographing the county's many locations, was an idyllic vocation that lasted six years, during which time I frequently made repeat trips to ensure that each location was captured in the right light, and at exactly the right moment. The huge number of photographs has been edited to just over 125, most at full page or double-spread size, and each accompanied by an extensive caption.
The ForewordWith the photography completed, this was one finishing touch needed before it could be published. I wanted someone who is a travel writer, someone who lives in Waterford, and above all, someone who appreciates its beauty. I had ample time whilst roaming the coast and mountains to think about it. My conclusion was that Dervla Murphy, the Irish author of over 24 adventure travel books covering the world from Ireland to India, Cuba to Capetown. Now an octogenerian, Dervla still travels, still writes and still lives in Lismore and was the perfect choice. I was delighted when, on showing her my landscape work, she liked it, and enthusiastically agreed to write a passage in her own inimatable style.Who am I?Since leaving photography college 40 years ago, I have worked in a number of genres. First as a photojournalist, then an advertising photographer, until I eventually specialised as a landscape photograper during my time as co-director of Slidefile, the photo-agency. During those years my work appeared in countless books, from large panoramic books to small Irish guide books for Reader's Digest and other international publishers; along with innumerable magazines and calendars. When I re-located to County Waterford ten years ago, I set up Copper Coast Workshops, to  teach digital photography, and conduct guided photo-tours.  Notwithstanding the fact that I'm now officially 'retired', my enjoyment when shooting the landscape has increased, and I still work on a very occasional, freelance basis for Tourism Ireland..."George’s love for his adopted country and especially of his adopted county of Waterford is reflected in the quality of the imagery he has consistently produced on commission for Tourism Ireland.  Imagery that has captured the imagination of and encouraged visitors to this island of Ireland" ....Patrick Lennon, Acting Content Manager, Tourism Ireland, "Since George retired and, to quote him, 'returned to landscape photography for passion, rather than profit', it's been an enjoyable few years following his work on his blog. He studies his subject in depth and the photography shot for his new book illustrates and reveals the rich, varied landscape and heritage of County Waterford to perfection" .... Shane O'Neill, Aspect Photography, Waterford.
Why your support is so importantThe book is now designed and ready to print, each part has been thoroughly and expertly compiled; the images, layout and design, dust jacket, interior pages and binding; and it's my fervant hope that I will be able to see it in print form. However, with 132 pages of superlative quality at a size of 10.5" X 11.75",  in a hard cover, it is very expensive. Which is why I need your support; and this is where Indiegogo and more especially - you - come in, because by backing this project, you can help me to achieve my goal.It's not without reward. To the right, is the list of the Perks that I'm offering for your support. Designed to give excellent value, the amounts are substantially less than the combined retail value of the items. For example, the book is substantially below the anticipated shop price; the Limited Edition Gallery prints - just 20 of each are considerably below my normal gallery prices. The 10 photographs, represent a small sample of the photography in the book and can be seen by clicking the Gallery tab above. Your financial support will ensure that the book will be immaculately finished, and you can show off this beautiful book and say, “I helped make it happen”.If we are fortunate enough to reach our goal, then the book will be available in August this year (2013).  If we are doubly fortunate to have an excess, it will initially be put towards enhancing existing perks and adding one or two new ones. 
The  Waterford bookshops have seen the book in digital form and would like to stock it, so we may also print a small number of additional copies. However, it's very unlikely that it will be available through on-line or overseas book shops.So please, please keep on contributing until the end of the campaign.  Whether you are able, or unable to take advantage of the perks, it would be a great help if you would share this project with your friends and colleagues through your social networks, Facebook, Twitter, Google+, blogs and emails etc. The more folk that know about it, the better its chance of succeeding. story:
Hey everyone!

After being asked by many people to come down to Colombia to film. I have made the big decision to head down to Colombia for TEP! This is huge for me but it comes at a bit of a risk.

I have already purchased the flights but I need your help to pay them off! If you can help at all please do!

I will be taking a ton of photos and making a video or two as well!! see you all there!

**************

¡Hola a todos!

Después de que muchas personas me pidieran que bajara a Colombia para filmar. ¡Después de pensarlo un poco, tomé la gran decisión de ir a Colombia para TEP! Esto es enorme para mí, pero tiene un poco de riesgo.

¡Ya compré los vuelos, pero necesito tu ayuda para pagarlos! Si puedes ayudar, por favor hazlo!

Tomaré muchísimas fotos y también haré un video o dos. los veo a todos allí!

story:
ABOUT

I'm doing my first photography showcase! If you're in Chicago, I'd love to see you there (see below for link to tix). If not, any help in supporting some costs to make the showcase happen are welcomed.

SHOWCASE INFO

Wednesday, Oct. 17 @ Metro Chicago from 7-11pm.

Tickets for the event can be found here: http://www.rawartists.org/lizography

*Make sure you use this direct link so the ticket count goes to my artist page

OUT OF TOWN/NOT IN CHICAGO?

To participate in the showcase, I have to sell 20 tickets ($22 each) otherwise I pay the remaining difference. Anything is appreciated to help supplement the cost of unsold tickets and support production costs. You can:

  • Donate a custom amount via Indiegogo
  • Still purchase a ticket to the event that will add to my ticket count

All donors will receive a free 4x4 print with a personal note from me. <3 Make sure you share your mailing address with me.

story:
For all information about the card game in English, please click here.
You can choose the language of the cards in the order process.


Warum ein Kartenspiel?


Das Quartettspiel kommt eigentlich aus den Niederlanden, ist aber in Deutschland schon seit Jahrzehnten sehr verbreitet. Wir haben bereits als Kinder Quartett gespielt und die verschiedenen Rennautos, Dinosaurier oder Fußballspieler miteinander verglichen. Ich weiß heute noch, dass der furchterregende T-Rex gar nicht so gut abgeschnitten hat und man mit den großen Pflanzenfressern oft viel bessere Gewinnchancen hatte. Auch ein paar der lateinischen Namen sind hängen geblieben.

Diesen Nebeneffekt möchten wir nutzen. Mit Hilfe des Kartenspiels hat man jede Menge Spaß und lernt nebenbei noch etwas über die Fotografie. Natürlich gibt es bereits einige tolle Bücher zur Kamerageschichte, aber wir mögen den spielerischen Zugang und haben uns deshalb für das Quartett entschieden.


Wie funktioniert Quartett?


Unser Quartettspiel kann man auf zwei verschiedene Weisen spielen. Für beide Varianten benötigt man mindestens zwei Spieler*innen. Natürlich wird sich auch im Spiel selbst eine genaue Anleitung befinden.

Klassisches Quartett:
Ziel des Spiels ist es, die meisten Quartette zu sammeln. Ein Quartett besteht aus vier Karten. Welche Karten ein Quartett bilden, erkennt man an den Symbolen auf den Karten.

Zunächst werden die Karten gemischt und verteilt. Die Person mit der größten Kamerasammlung beginnt und fragt eine beliebige Person nach einer Karte, die ihr zur Bildung eines Quartetts fehlt, etwa „Hast Du die Boxkamera Nr. 4?“

Hat die Person die gesuchte Karte, muss sie sie herausgeben und die fragende Person darf weiterhin fehlende Karten fordern. Wenn jedoch die gewünschte Karte nicht im Besitz ist, dann ist die befragte Person an der Reihe.

Sobald jemand ein vollständiges Quartett, etwa vier Mittelformatkameras, besitzt, legt man dieses offen vor sich auf den Tisch. Das Spiel endet, wenn die Karten aufgebraucht und alle Quartette abgelegt sind. Wer bis zum Spielende die meisten Quartette sammeln konnte, gewinnt.


Supertrumpf:
Unserer persönlicher Favorit. Die Karten werden gemischt und gleichmäßig an alle Spieler*innen verteilt. Man hält die Karten zu einem Päckchen gestapelt so in der Hand, dass nur das oberste Blatt für einen selbst zu sehen ist.

Die Person mit der größten Kamerasammlung beginnt und nennt nun einen beliebigen Vergleichswert auf ihrer Karte. Zum Beispiel: „Gewicht: 1400 g“. Die Mitspieler*innen nennen nun die entsprechenden Daten auf ihrer obersten Karte. Der beste Wert gewinnt und derjenige erhält alle Karten, die in der Runde vorgelesen wurden. Ob leichtere oder schwerere Kameras „besser“ sind, muss vor dem Spielstart vereinbart werden. Die Person mit dem besten Wert legt die gewonnen Karten unter ihren Kartenstapel und ist nun an der Reihe, einen Wert zu wählen. Gewonnen hat, wer zuletzt alle Karten besitzt.

Wie weit seid Ihr?


Die Idee wurde bereits Anfang 2017 geboren und nahm im Lauf der Monate immer weiter Gestalt an. Wir haben uns mit den verschiedenen Kameramodellen auseinandergesetzt, uns in die Kamerageschichte eingelesen und die schönsten und wichtigsten Kameras in Quartette aufgeteilt. Auch die Vergleichswerte sind zum Großteil bereits herausgesucht.

Wir haben Kontakt zu den verschiedenen Kameraherstellern aufgenommen, um rechtliche Punkte zu klären. Bis auf eine Firma haben alle unsere Idee sehr positiv aufgenommen und uns die Erlaubnis gegeben, ihre Markennamen zu verwenden!

Wir konnten die großartige Illustratorin Regina Cekaskin für die Zeichnungen der Kameras gewinnen, die uns schon in der Vergangenheit bei anderen Produkten wie unserer Baumwolltasche unterstützt hat. Um das Kartendesign kümmert sich Fotografin und Designerin Lisa-Marie Kaspar. Die beiden haben für diese Kampagne die ersten drei Karten gezeichnet sowie gestaltet und wir hoffen, Du bist von ihrer Arbeit genauso begeistert wie wir. Sobald die Finanzierung steht, werden sich die beiden an die Arbeit für die restlichen Karten machen.

 

 

Welche Vergleichswerte habt Ihr?

 

  • Erscheinungsjahr: Das jeweilige Erscheinungsjahr der Kameras.
  • Gewicht: Wieviel wiegt die Kamera? Diese Angabe steht häufig leider nicht in den alten Werbeanzeigen und Katalogen. Und wenn doch, wurde die Kamera mit oder ohne Objektiv, mit Prisma- oder Schachtsucher gewogen? Teilweise haben wir einige Kameras selbst auf die Waage gestellt oder Freund*innen, Bekannte und unsere Leser*innen dazu angestiftet.
  • Preis damals: Wieviel hat die Kamera an ihrem Erscheinungsjahr gekostet? Je nach Währung und Zeit ist dieser Wert nur schwer zu vergleichen. Wir haben deshalb die Angaben umgerechnet. Die Preise sind im deutschen Quartett in € (im englischen in USD) angegeben und entsprechen dem Wert, den die Kameras im Verhältnis zu den Lebenskosten hatten.
  • Preis heute: Wieviel kostet die Kamera heute? Wir haben uns Preise bei Auktionen und Second-Hand-Shops angesehen. Die Preise schwanken je nach Zustand und Glück der Käufer*innen zum Teil. Wir geben im Quartett den Durchschnittspreis einer gut erhaltenen und noch funktionstüchtigen Kamera an.
  • Google-Treffer: Dieser Punkt war in der Redaktion zugegeben der umstrittenste. Natürlich ist er sehr einfach zu ermitteln, aber darum geht es uns nicht allein. Die Anzahl der Google-Treffer verrät vor allem etwas über die Bekanntheit der Kameras.
  • Innovationswert: Hier möchten wir aufzeigen, wie wichtig die jeweilige Kamera für die Entwicklung der Kameratechnik war. Gab es bei den jeweiligen Modellen technische Neuerungen, die den Fortschritt der Fotografie vorangetrieben haben, dann bekommt die Kamera von uns einen höheren Innovationswert. Natürlich ist dieser zugegeben etwas subjektiv. Unsere Skala reicht von 1 bis 10.

Die Vergleichswerte stehen relativ fest. Wir können Dir sagen: Es war gar nicht so einfach, geeignete vergleichbare Werte zu finden und einige gute Ideen, wie zum Beispiel die Anzahl der verkauften Exemplare oder der Produktionszeitraum, mussten wir verwerfen, weil wir darüber nicht genügend Informationen gefunden haben.

Auf jeder Karte steht zum Schluss noch ein kleiner Text über die Kamera. So bekommst Du noch ein wenig mehr Informationen und erfährst, was die Kamera ausmacht und für was sie besonders bekannt ist.


Wie sind die Quartette unterteilt?


Wir verstehen, dass Du neugierig bist, deshalb legen wir die Karten sprichwörtlich auf den Tisch: Das klassische Spiel besteht aus 32 Karten. Daraus ergeben sich dann acht Quartette. Wir planen aktuell 36 Karten mit neun Quartetten. Eventuell müssen wir es am Ende noch auf die klassische Anzahl reduzieren. Die Entscheidung hängt leider von verschiedenen Faktoren ab.

Die neun momentan geplanten Quartette sind: Mittelformatkameras, Großformatkameras, Kleinbildkameras vor 1960, Kleinbildkameras nach 1960, Lomography,  Sofortbildkameras, Pocketfilmkameras, Boxkameras und Zweiäugige Kameras.


Und warum ein Crowdfunding?


Wir sind natürlich begeistert von unserer Idee und würden unglaublich gern dieses Spiel zum Leben erwecken. Unsere finanziellen Möglichkeiten sind allerdings begrenzt und ein Kartenspiel ist nicht so günstig wie man zu Beginn vielleicht denkt.

Wir haben schon sehr viel Arbeit und Zeit investiert und sind nun an einem Punkt, an dem wir auch Arbeit an externe Fachkräfte, wie unsere Zeichnerin und Designerin weitergeben müssen. Wir wollen das Kartenspiel in einer deutschen und englischen Variante auf den Markt bringen, weshalb wir gute Übersetzungen brauchen und natürlich soll am Ende auch noch einmal ein externer Experte über unsere ausgewählten Kameramodelle und Vergleichszahlen sehen. Das Ganze ist zwar ein Spiel, aber uns ist wichtig, dass die Daten alle korrekt sind. Zu guter Letzt kommen natürlich auch noch die Druckkosten dazu.

Wir möchten uns über das Crowdfunding absichern und wissen, ob unsere Idee wirklich genügend Fans findet, sodass all diese externe Arbeit gerechtfertigt ist und am Ende auch bezahlt werden kann. Möchtest Du uns dabei helfen?

 

Wie läuft die Finanzierung genau?


Das Finanzierungsziel ist mit 8.000 € beim absoluten Minimum angesetzt. Wir gehen in unserer Beispielrechnung von einem Druck von insgesamt 1.000 Kartenspielen im Faltkarton aus:


Wie sieht der Zeitplan aus?

 

Sobald die Finanzierung erfolgreich ist, wird unsere Illustratorin Regina damit beginnen, alle übrigen Kameras zu zeichnen. In dieser Zeit lassen wir auch unsere Werte auf den Karten überprüfen und rechnen unsere bisherigen deutschen Gewichts- und Preisangaben in die amerikanisch-englischen Formate um.

Anschließend bekommt unsere Designerin Lisa-Marie alle Zeichnungen und Werte und gestaltet die Spielkarten. Im Anschluss gehen die Karten nach einer letzten Kontrolle in den Druck und wir freuen uns darauf, sie in alle Welt zu verschicken und natürlich endlich zu spielen!


Welche Risiken gibt es?
 

Für Dich gibt es keine Risiken. Sollte das Projekt nicht vor Ablauf der Zeit finanziert werden, wird es leider kein Kartenspiel geben, aber Du erhältst natürlich Dein Geld zurück! Für uns heißt es dann von der Idee Abschied nehmen, was nach all der bisherigen Arbeit nicht leicht wird. Aus eigener Tasche können und werden wir das Projekt nicht verwirklichen können.

Wir hoffen natürlich, dass unser Projekt Erfolg hat. Für diesen Fall haben wir Angebote der Druckerei, Designerin, Illustratorin und Übersetzerin eingeholt und mit ihren Preis- und Zeitvorstellungen einen Kosten- und Zeitplan erstellt. Wir sind uns bewusst, dass immer irgendetwas länger dauern kann oder Fehler passieren und dafür Zeitpuffer eingeplant. Sollten wir unseren Zeitplan aus unvorhersehbaren Gründen nicht einhalten können, halten wir Dich auf jeden Fall in den Updates auf dem Laufenden!

Wir haben mit ähnlichen Projekten bereits Erfahrungen: Seit 2016 verkaufen wir erfolgreich etwa alle zwei Monate 300 Überraschungsboxen für Fotograf*innen, gefüllt mit verschiedenen Produkten rund um die Fotografie. Die Planung und der Versand vieler Pakete sind uns also nicht neu.
 

Unsere Perks


Neben dem Kartenspiel gibt es noch zwei weitere kleine Perks, die wir Euch kurz vorstellen möchten.

Baumwolltasche: Unsere Baumwolltasche wurde, wie die Kameras für das Quartett, von Regina Cekaskin gestaltet. Sie wurde aus Baumwollresten, die bei der Produktion anderer Taschen eigentlich als Abfall zurückbleiben, neu verwebt. Mit einer Grammatur von 180 g/m² ist sie zudem sehr robust und reißfest. Mit den langen Henkeln kannst Du ganz bequem Dein Hobby nach außen tragen.



Postkarten: Die schönsten Vintagekameras als als Zeichnungen auf Postkarten bekommt Ihr mit diesem Perk. Wir verschicken gleich fünf zufällig ausgewählte Kamerazeichnungen. Gedruckt werden sie auf Premium-Papier mit matten Finish.
